pyTTN

pyTTN package

The pyTTN package: An Open Source Toolbox for Quantum Dynamics Simulations Using Tree Tensor Networks.

Subpackages

  • pyttn.linalg package
    • Module contents
  • pyttn.models package

Module contents

pyttn.SOP(*args, dtype=<class 'numpy.complex128'>)[source]

Factory function for constructing a sum-of-product compact string operator.

Parameters:

  • *args –

    Variable length list of arguments. This function can handle two possible lists of arguments

    • N (int) - The number of modes of the SOP

    • N (int), label (str) - The number of modes of the SOP and a label for the SOP

  • dtype ({np.float64, np.complex128}, optional) – The dtype to use for the site operator. (Default: np.complex128)

Returns:

The SOP object

Return type:

SOP_real or SOP_complex

pyttn.boson_mode(arg0: int) → pyttn.ttnpp.primitive_mode_data

Create a new mode_data object for a mode with Fermionic Exchange Statistics

Parameters:

N (int) – The local Hilbert space dimension to use for the mode

Returns:

bosonic mode data object

Return type:

mode_data

pyttn.coeff(coeff, dtype=<class 'numpy.complex128'>)[source]

A function for constructing the coeff type for Hamiltonian specification

Parameters:

  • coeff –

    A variable list for specifying the coefficient. Valid options are

    • Default construct the coefficient

    • value (dtype) - Set the coefficient to a constant value

    • func (callable) - set the coefficient to a time-dependent value

  • dtype ({np.float64, np.complex128}, optional) – The internal variable type for the product operator.

Returns:

The coefficient object

Return type:

coeff_real or coeff_complex

pyttn.combine_systems(arg0: pyttn.ttnpp.system_modes, arg1: pyttn.ttnpp.system_modes) → pyttn.ttnpp.system_modes

A function for creating a new system_modes object by composing two system_modes objects together. This function appends the second system_modes objects modes to the first and additionally, where user defined mode orderings have been specified, shifts the ordering of the modes correspond to the second object. By the number of modes in the first object.

Parameters:

  • sysA (system_modes) – The first system mode variable

  • sysB (system_modes) – The second system mode variable

Returns:

The combined system_modes object.

Return type:

system_modes

pyttn.dmrg(A, H, expansion='onesite', **kwargs)[source]

A factory method for constructing an object used for performing either single or multi set dmrg calculations. Which type to construct is determined by the types of the input A and h matrices. For details on the use of these DMRG objects please see the documentation associated with the possible return types.

Parameters:

  • A (ttn_complex or ms_ttn_complex) – Tree Tensor Network that the DMRG algorithm will act on

  • H (sop_operator_complex) – The Hamiltonian sop operator object

  • expansion ({'onesite', 'subspace'}, optional) – A string determining the type of bond dimension expansion to be used. Either no subspace expansion (‘onesite’) or energy variance based (‘subspace’). (Default: ‘onesite’)

  • **kwargs – Keyword arguments to pass to the DMRG engine constructor. For details see one_site_dmrg_complex or adaptive_one_site_dmrg_complex

Returns:

The DMRG evaluation object

Return type:

one_site_dmrg_complex or adaptive_one_site_dmrg_complex or multiset_one_site_dmrg_complex

pyttn.fOP(arg0: str, arg1: int) → pyttn.ttnpp.sOP

Create a new site operator string where the operator is a Fermionic operator.

Parameters:

  • arg0 (str) – The operator label associated with this operator.

  • arg1 (int) – The mode this operator acts upon.

For fermionic systems the following operator are supported:

  • Annihilation operator \(\hat{c}\) : {“c”, “a”, “f”}

  • Creation operator \(\hat{c}^\dagger\) : {“cdag”, “adag”, “fdag”, “cd”, “ad”, “fd”}

  • Number operator \(\hat{c}^\dagger\hat{c}\) : {“n”, “cdagc”, “adaga”, “fdagf”, “cdc”, “ada”, “fdf”}

  • Vacancy operator \(1-\hat{c}^\dagger\hat{c}\) : {“v”}

Returns:

fermionic mode data object

Return type:

mode_data

fermionic mode data object

pyttn.fermion_operator(arg0: str, arg1: int) → pyttn.ttnpp.sOP

Create a new site operator string where the operator is a Fermionic operator.

Parameters:

  • arg0 (str) – The operator label associated with this operator.

  • arg1 (int) – The mode this operator acts upon.

For fermionic systems the following operator are supported:

  • Annihilation operator \(\hat{c}\) : {“c”, “a”, “f”}

  • Creation operator \(\hat{c}^\dagger\) : {“cdag”, “adag”, “fdag”, “cd”, “ad”, “fd”}

  • Number operator \(\hat{c}^\dagger\hat{c}\) : {“n”, “cdagc”, “adaga”, “fdagf”, “cdc”, “ada”, “fdf”}

  • Vacancy operator \(1-\hat{c}^\dagger\hat{c}\) : {“v”}

Returns:

fermionic mode data object

Return type:

pyttn.generic_mode(arg0: int) → pyttn.ttnpp.primitive_mode_data

Create a new genric mode mode_data object with arbitrary Hilbert space dimension. When using such a mode it is necessary for the user to define all operators acting on this mode.

Parameters:

N (int) – The local Hilbert space dimension to use for the mode

Returns:

generic mode data object

Return type:

mode_data

pyttn.liouville_space_superoperator(Op, sys, optype, opdict=None, Lopdict=None, coeff=1.0)[source]

A function for taking a Hilbert space operator and system information object and constructing a Liouville space operator object rdependent on the argument optype. Here we support the automatic generation of 4 different types of Liouville space operator these are left acting operators, right acting operators, commutator operators and anticommutator operators.

To Do: Add parameters

pyttn.matrix_element(*args, dtype=<class 'numpy.complex128'>, **kwargs)[source]

A factory method for constructing an object used for evaluating matrix elements from a TTN. If this function is passed a TTN object it uses this to construct a matrix_element suitable for evaluating matrix elements of this class. Otherwise this will construct an empty matrix_element object with the required dtype.

Parameters:

  • *args (empty or single ttn_complex, ttn_real, ms_ttn_complex, ms_ttn_real) – A variable length set of arguments that is either empty or contains the TTN that we will want to evaluate matrix elements of.

  • dtype ({np.float64, np.complex128}, optional) – The type to be stored in the matrix element object. This is ignored if the a TTN object is passed in the first argument.

  • **kwargs – Keyword arguments to pass to the matrix element engine constructor. For details see matrix_element_real or matrix_element_complex

Returns:

The matrix_element object

Return type:

matrix_element_real or matrix_element_complex

class pyttn.mode_data(*args, **kwargs)

Bases: pybind11_object

A class for handling information about composite modes used to represent the system information. This class stores a set of primitive_mode_data defining each individual mode that forms this composite, and provides several helper functions for determining the properties of the underlying modes. This functions support several overloaded constructors.

Overloaded function.

  1. __init__(self: pyttn.ttnpp.mode_data) -> None

Default construct an empty mode data object.

  1. __init__(self: pyttn.ttnpp.mode_data, arg0: int) -> None

    Construct a mode data object consisting of a single generic primitive mode with a given local Hilbert space dimension

    Parameters:

    • d (int) - Local Hilbert space dimension

  2. __init__(self: pyttn.ttnpp.mode_data, arg0: int, arg1: pyttn.ttnpp.mode_type) -> None

    Construct a mode data object consisting of a single mode primitive mode with a given local Hilbert space dimension

    Parameters:

    • d (int) - Local Hilbert space dimension

    • type (mode_type) - The type of mode to construct

  3. __init__(self: pyttn.ttnpp.mode_data, arg0: pyttn.ttnpp.mode_data) -> None

    Construct a mode data object from another mode data object

    Parameters:

    • data (mode_data) - The mode data object to construct from

  4. __init__(self: pyttn.ttnpp.mode_data, arg0: pyttn.ttnpp.primitive_mode_data) -> None

    Construct a mode data object consisting of a single primitive mode

    Parameters:

    • data (primitive_mode_data) - The value of the primitive mode to use

    Construct a mode data object from a vector of primitive_mode_data objects

    Parameters:

    • data (list[primitive_mode_data]) - A list of primitive mode data objects that form the composite mode

lhd(self: pyttn.ttnpp.mode_data) → int

Return the local Hilbert space dimension of the composite mode. This is the product of the local Hilbert space dimensions of the primitive modes

liouville_space(self: pyttn.ttnpp.mode_data) → pyttn.ttnpp.mode_data

Constructs a new mode_data object that corresponds to a Liouville space representation of this object. This is done by taking each mode and appending a dual space operator following this mode of the same type.

Returns:

Liouville space mode_data object

Return type:

mode_data

class pyttn.mode_type(self: pyttn.ttnpp.mode_type, value: int)

Bases: pybind11_object

The type of a mode

Members:

fermion_mode : Flag for setting a mode to be a fermion

boson_mode : Flag for setting a mode to be a boson

spin_mode : Flag for setting a mode to be a spin degree of freedom

tls_mode : Flag for setting a mode to be a two-level system degree of freedom

generic_mode : Flag for setting a mode to be an unknown generic mode

__str__(*args, **kwargs)

Overloaded function.

pyttn.ms_ttn(*args, dtype=<class 'numpy.complex128'>, **kwargs)[source]

Factory function for constructing a multiset tree tensor network state operator

Parameters:

  • *args –

    Variable length list of arguments. This function can handle two possible lists of arguments

    • Default construct a multiset TTN object

    • msttn (ms_ttn_dtype) - Copy construct a multiset TTN object

    • tree (ntree), nset (int) - Construct a multiset TTN from an Ntree object and the number of set variables

    • string (str), nset (int) - Construct multiset TTN from an string defining an Ntree object and the number of set variables

  • dtype ({np.float64, np.complex128}, optional) – The dtype to use for the site operator. (Default: np.complex128)

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments that are based to the ttn object constructor

Returns:

The Multiset Tree Tensor Network State object

Return type:

ms_ttn_real or ms_ttn_complex

  • dtype ({np.float64, np.complex128}, optional) – The dtype to use for the site operator. (Default: np.complex128)

class pyttn.ntree(*args, **kwargs)

Bases: pybind11_object

A class for handling a generic tree structure that stores an integer at each node. Within pyTTN this class is used to represent the topology of the tree tensor network, with the integers stored at a node corresponding to the number of single-particle functions (basis functions) associated with this node. Alternatively, this can be viewed as the bond-dimension connecting the node with its parent. In the current version we require the root node to have a value of 1, which corresponds to a topology representing a single state.

Overloaded function.

  1. __init__(self: pyttn.ttnpp.ntree) -> None

Default construct an empty ntree.

  1. __init__(self: pyttn.ttnpp.ntree, arg0: pyttn.ttnpp.ntree) -> None

    Copy construct an ntree from another ntree object

    Parameters:

    • tree (ntree) - Input ntree to construct a copy of

  2. __init__(self: pyttn.ttnpp.ntree, arg0: str) -> None

    Copy construct an ntree from a string representation of a tree. Here we use a set of nested parentheses to represent a tree e.g.:

    (1(2(3)(4))(5(6)(7))

    corresponds to the tree

    1

    x x

    x x

    2 5

    x x x x

    x x x x

    3 4 6 7

    Parameters:

    • tree (str) - A string representation of a tree

__call__(*args, **kwargs)

Overloaded function.

    ntreeNode

bfs(self: pyttn.ttnpp.ntree) → Iterator[pyttn.ttnpp.ntreeNode]
Returns:

An iterator for traversing the list in breadth first search order

clear(self: pyttn.ttnpp.ntree) → None

Deallocate all internal storage of the ntree object. Setting it so that it has no nodes.

dfs(self: pyttn.ttnpp.ntree) → Iterator[pyttn.ttnpp.ntreeNode]
Returns:

An iterator for traversing the list in depth first search order

Returns:

Returns whether or not the ntree object is empty. That is it contains no nodes.

Return type:

bool

An iterator for performing an euler tour of the nodes

insert(self: pyttn.ttnpp.ntree, arg0: int) → None

Insert a new root node into the tree. If the tree already contains a root node this will throw an exception.

Parameters:

val (int) – The data to store at the root node

insert_at(self: pyttn.ttnpp.ntree, arg0: list[int], arg1: int) → None

Insert an element as a child of a specific node in the tree. Here the position is defined by a list of numbers that define which child to traverse down at each node of the tree. If the list is empty this attempts to insert a new root.

Parameters:

  • inds (list[int]) – The index of the node where we aim to insert a child.

  • val (int) – The data to store at the root node

load(self: pyttn.ttnpp.ntree, arg0: str) → None

Load an ntree object from a string representation of a tree. Here we use a set of nested parentheses to represent a tree e.g.:

(1(2(3)(4))(5(6)(7))

corresponds to the tree

1

x x

x x

2 5

x x x x

x x x x

3 4 6 7

Parameters:

  • tree (str) - A string representation of a tree

Return type:

int

static mlmctdh_subtree(*args, **kwargs)

Overloaded function.

  1. mlmctdh_subtree(arg0: pyttn.ttnpp.ntreeNode, arg1: list[int], arg2: int, arg3: Callable[[int], int], include_local_basis_transformation: bool = True) -> None

    Append a new balanced ntree for representing a tensor with dimensions specified in a list, of degree d, using an integer to specify the internal bond dimensions.

    Parameters:

    • node (ntreeNode) - The node to append the tree to

    • dims (list[int]) - The local Hilbert space dimensions of each leaf of the tree

    • degree (int) - The degree of the tree structure. 2 corresponds to a balanced binary tree.

    • chi (int) - A fixed internal bond dimension to use throughout the tree.

    • include_local_basis_transformation (bool, optional) - A flag as to or not to include a set of bond matrices at the leaves of the tree defining a local basis transformation. (Default: True)

  2. mlmctdh_subtree(arg0: pyttn.ttnpp.ntreeNode, arg1: list[int], arg2: int, arg3: int, include_local_basis_transformation: bool = True) -> None

    Append a new balanced ntree for representing a tensor with dimensions specified in a list, of degree d, using a function that depends on the distance from the root to specify the internal bond dimensions.

    Parameters:

    • node (ntreeNode) - The node to append the tree to

    • dims (list[int]) - The local Hilbert space dimensions of each leaf of the tree

    • degree (int) - The degree of the tree structure. 2 corresponds to a balanced binary tree.

    • fchi (callable(int)) - A function specifying the bond dimension as a function of depth.

    • include_local_basis_transformation (bool, optional) - A flag as to or not to include a set of bond matrices at the leaves of the tree defining a local basis transformation. (Default: True)

  3. mlmctdh_subtree(arg0: pyttn.ttnpp.ntreeNode, arg1: list[int], arg2: int, arg3: Callable[[int], int], arg4: int) -> None

    Append a new balanced ntree for representing a tensor with dimensions specified in a list, of degree d, using a function that depends on the distance from the root to specify the internal bond dimensions. Additionally, this function inserts a local basis transformation with a user specified dimension to each of the leaf nodes.

    Parameters:

    • node (ntreeNode) - The node to append the tree to

    • dims (list[int]) - The local Hilbert space dimensions of each leaf of the tree

    • degree (int) - The degree of the tree structure. 2 corresponds to a balanced binary tree.

    • chi (int) - A fixed internal bond dimension to use throughout the tree.

    • lhd (int) - The variable used for defining the number of individual mode states to retain in the tree structure

  4. mlmctdh_subtree(arg0: pyttn.ttnpp.ntreeNode, arg1: list[int], arg2: int, arg3: int, arg4: int) -> None

    Append a new balanced ntree for representing a tensor with dimensions specified in a list, of degree d, using a function that depends on the distance from the root to specify the internal bond dimensions. Additionally, this function inserts a local basis transformation with a user specified dimension to each of the leaf nodes.

    Parameters:

    • node (ntreeNode) - The node to append the tree to

    • dims (list[int]) - The local Hilbert space dimensions of each leaf of the tree

    • degree (int) - The degree of the tree structure. 2 corresponds to a balanced binary tree.

    • fchi (callable(int)) - A function specifying the bond dimension as a function of depth.

    • lhd (int) - The variable used for defining the number of individual mode states to retain in the tree structure

  5. mlmctdh_subtree(arg0: pyttn.ttnpp.ntreeNode, arg1: list[int], arg2: int, arg3: Callable[[int], int], arg4: list[int]) -> None

    Append a new balanced ntree for representing a tensor with dimensions specified in a list, of degree d, using a function that depends on the distance from the root to specify the internal bond dimensions. Additionally, this function inserts a local basis transformation with a user specified dimension to each of the leaf nodes.

    Parameters:

    • node (ntreeNode) - The node to append the tree to

    • dims (list[int]) - The local Hilbert space dimensions of each leaf of the tree

    • degree (int) - The degree of the tree structure. 2 corresponds to a balanced binary tree.

    • chi (int) - A fixed internal bond dimension to use throughout the tree.

    • lhd (list[int]) - The variable used for defining the number of individual mode states to retain in the tree structure. Here this is different for each leaf of the tree.

  6. mlmctdh_subtree(arg0: pyttn.ttnpp.ntreeNode, arg1: list[int], arg2: int, arg3: int, arg4: list[int]) -> None

    • fchi (callable(int)) - A function specifying the bond dimension as a function of depth.

    • lhd (list[int]) - The variable used for defining the number of individual mode states to retain in the tree structure. Here this is different for each leaf of the tree.

static sanitise(arg0: pyttn.ttnpp.ntree, remove_bond_matrices: bool = True) → None

Sanitise an ntree to ensure that it corresponds to a valid structure for TTN and if specified does not have any bond matrices.

Parameters:

  • tree (bool, optional) – The tree to sanitise. This tree is overwritten by the sanitised structure.

  • remove_bond_matrices – A flag as to whether or not to remove bond matrices. (Default: True)

static sanitise_bond_dimensions(arg0: pyttn.ttnpp.ntree) → None

Alter the bond dimensions within the tree such that we do not have any bonds where we have a larger dimension than the number of states.

Parameters:

tree (ntree) – The tree to edit. This tree is overwritten in this process.

pyttn.sNBO(*args, dtype=<class 'numpy.complex128'>)[source]

A function for constructing an n-body operator string

Parameters:

  • *args –

    A variable list for specifying the coefficient. Valid options are

    • Default construct the sNBO

    • op (sOP) - Construct NBO from single site operator

    • pop (sPOP) - Construct NBO from product operator

    • arg (dtype), op (sOP) - Construct NBO as a product of a constant and a single site operator

    • arg (dtype), pop (sPOP) - Construct NBO as a product of a constant and a product operator

    • arg (coeff), op (sOP) - Construct NBO as a product of a coefficient and a single site operator

    • arg (coeff), pop (sPOP) - Construct NBO as a product of a coefficient and a product operator

    • nbo (sNBO) - Construct NBO from another NBO

  • dtype ({np.float64, np.complex128}, optional) – The internal variable type for the n-body operator string.

Returns:

The n-body operator object

Return type:

sNBO_real or sNBO_complex

class pyttn.sOP(*args, **kwargs)

Bases: pybind11_object

The single site operator used for the string operator handling functionality of pyTTN. This class allows for definition of a string label for an operator and the mode that the operator acts upon. In addition to allowing for arbitrary string labels with the combination of user defined operator dictionaries. This code supports several automatic dictionaries depending on the type of mode considered. These are

Fermion Modes:

  • Annihilation operator \(\hat{c}\) : {“c”, “a”, “f”}

  • Creation operator \(\hat{c}^\dagger\) : {“cdag”, “adag”, “fdag”, “cd”, “ad”, “fd”}

  • Number operator \(\hat{c}^\dagger\hat{c}\) : {“n”, “cdagc”, “adaga”, “fdagf”, “cdc”, “ada”, “fdf”}

  • Vacancy operator \(1-\hat{c}^\dagger\hat{c}\) : “v”

Bosonic Modes:

  • Annihilation operator \(\hat{c}\) : {“c”, “a”, “b”}

  • Creation operator \(\hat{c}^\dagger\) : {“cdag”, “adag”, “bdag”, “cd”, “ad”, “bd”}

  • Number operator \(\hat{c}^\dagger\hat{c}\) : {“n”, “cdagc”, “adaga”, “bdagb”, “cdc”, “ada”, “bdb”}

  • Position operator \(hat{q}\) : {“q”, “x”}

  • Momentum opeartor \(hat{p}\) : “p”

Spin Modes for arbitrary spin S:

  • \(\hat{S}_x\) : {“sx”, “x”}

  • \(\hat{S}_y\) : {“sy”, “y”}

  • \(\hat{S}_z\) : {“sz”, “z”}

  • \(\hat{S}_+\) : {“s+”, “sp”}

  • \(\hat{S}_-\) : {“s-”, “sm”}

Two Level System Modes:

  • \(\hat{\sigma}_x\) : {“sx”, “x”, “sigmax”}

  • \(\hat{\sigma}_y\) : {“sy”, “y”, “sigmay”}

  • \(\hat{\sigma}_z\) : {“sz”, “z”, “sigmaz”}

  • \(\hat{\sigma}_+\) : {“s+”, “sp”, “sigma+”, “sigmap”}

  • \(\hat{\sigma}_-\) : {“s-”, “sm”, “sigma-”, “sigmam”}

Overloaded function.

class pyttn.sPOP(*args, **kwargs)

Bases: pybind11_object

A product of sOP operators. This function handles the fact that in general sOP operators do not commute.

pyttn.sSOP(*args, dtype=<class 'numpy.complex128'>)[source]

A function for constructing a sum-of-product string operator

Parameters:

  • *args –

    A variable list for specifying the coefficient. Valid options are

    • Default construct the sSOP

    • op (str) - Construct the sSOP from a string defining a sOP

    • op (sOP) - Construct sSOP from single site operator

    • pop (sPOP) - Construct sSOP from product operator

    • nbo (sNBO) - Construct sSOP from an sNBO

    • sop (sSOP) - Construct sSOP from another sSOP

  • dtype ({np.float64, np.complex128}, optional) – The internal variable type for the sum-of-product string operator.

Returns:

The sum-of-product string operator

Return type:

sSOP_real or sSOP_complex

pyttn.single_set_dmrg(A, H, expansion='onesite', **kwargs)[source]

A factory method for constructing an object used for performing single set dmrg calculations

Parameters:

  • A (ttn_complex) – Tree Tensor Network that the DMRG algorithm will act on

  • H (sop_operator_complex) – The Hamiltonian sop operator object

  • expansion ({'onesite', 'subspace'}, optional) – A string determining the type of bond dimension expansion to be used. Either no subspace expansion (‘onesite’) or energy variance based (‘subspace’). (Default: ‘onesite’)

  • **kwargs – Keyword arguments to pass to the DMRG engine constructor. For details see one_site_dmrg_complex or adaptive_one_site_dmrg_complex

Returns:

The DMRG evaluation object

Return type:

one_site_dmrg_complex or adaptive_one_site_dmrg_complex

pyttn.single_set_tdvp(A, H, expansion='onesite', **kwargs)[source]

A factory method for constructing an object used for performing single set TDVP calculations

Parameters:

  • A (ttn_complex) – Tree Tensor Network that the DMRG algorithm will act on

  • H (sop_operator_complex) – The Hamiltonian sop operator object

  • expansion ({'onesite', 'subspace'}, optional) – A string determining the type of bond dimension expansion to be used. Either no subspace expansion (‘onesite’) or energy variance based (‘subspace’). (Default: ‘onesite’)

  • **kwargs – Keyword arguments to pass to the DMRG engine constructor. For details see one_site_dmrg_complex or adaptive_one_site_tdvp_complex

Returns:

The TDVP evaluation object

Return type:

one_site_tdvp_complex or adaptive_one_site_tdvp_complex

pyttn.site_operator(*args, mode=None, optype=None, dtype=<class 'numpy.complex128'>, **kwargs)[source]

Factory function for constructing a one site operator.

Parameters:

  • *args –

    Variable length list of arguments. There are several valid options for the *args parameters. If the optype variable is None the allowed options are

    • site_op (site_operator_real or site_operato_complex) - Construct a new site_operator object from the existing object

    • op (sOP), sysinf (system_modes) - Construct a new site_operator from the string operator and system information

    • op (sOP), sysinf (system_modes), opdict (operator_dictionary_real or operator_dictionary_complex) - Construct a new site_operator from the string operator, system information and used defined operator dictionary.

    Otherwise, if the optype variable has been set then the valid arguments are determined by the specified optype see opsExt.py for details.

  • mode (int or None, optional) – The mode the site operator is acting on. (Default: None)

  • optype ({'identity', 'matrix', 'sparse_matrix', 'diagonal_matrix'} or None, optional) – The type of the operator to be constructed. (Default: None)

  • dtype ({np.float64, np.complex128}, optional) – The dtype to use for the site operator. (Default: np.complex128)

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments. To construct the site_operator object

pyttn.sop_operator(h: None | SOP_complex, A: None | ttn_complex, sysinf: system_modes, *args, **kwargs)[source]

Function for constructing the hierarchical sum of product operator of a string operator

Parameters:

  • h (SOP_real or SOP_complex) – The sum of product operator representation of the Hamiltonian

  • A (ttn_real or ttn_complex) – A TTN object with defining the topology of output hierarchical SOP object

  • sysinf (system_modes) – The composition of the system defining the default dictionary to be considered for each node

class pyttn.system_modes(*args, **kwargs)

Bases: pybind11_object

A class for handling the specification of all modes in the system. This stores a list of each composite mode and an optional user supplied ordering of the modes

Overloaded function.

append(self: pyttn.ttnpp.system_modes, arg0: pyttn.ttnpp.system_modes) → None

Append the set of modes contained in the system_modes object to the back of this system. This function preserves the ordering of the modes in the two system objects but shifts the index in the new modes so that they occur after the current modes

Parameters:

sys (system_modes) – The new system modes to append to the end of this object

liouville_space(self: pyttn.ttnpp.system_modes) → pyttn.ttnpp.system_modes

Constructs a new system_modes object that corresponds to a Liouville space representation of this object. This is done by taking each mode and appending a dual space operator following this mode of the same type.

pyttn.tdvp(A, H, expansion='onesite', **kwargs)[source]

A factory method for constructing an object used for performing either single or multi set tdvp calculations. Which type to construct is determined by the types of the input A and h matrices.

Parameters:

  • A (ttn_complex or ms_ttn_complex) – Tree Tensor Network that the DMRG algorithm will act on

  • H (sop_operator_complex) – The Hamiltonian sop operator object

  • expansion ({'onesite', 'subspace'}, optional) – A string determining the type of bond dimension expansion to be used. Either no subspace expansion (‘onesite’) or energy variance based (‘subspace’). (Default: ‘onesite’)

  • **kwargs – Keyword arguments to pass to the DMRG engine constructor. For details see one_site_tdvp_complex or adaptive_one_site_tdvp_complex

Returns:

The TDVP evaluation object

Return type:

one_site_tdvp_complex or adaptive_one_site_tdvp_complex or multiset_one_site_tdvp_complex

pyttn.tls_mode() → pyttn.ttnpp.primitive_mode_data

Create a new mode_data object for a qubit. That is a two level system that Pauli operators can act upon

Returns:

qubit mode data object

Return type:

mode_data

pyttn.ttn(*args, dtype=<class 'numpy.complex128'>, **kwargs)[source]

Factory function for constructing a tree tensor network state operator

Parameters:

  • *args –

    Variable length list of arguments. This function can handle two possible lists of arguments

    • Default construct TTN object

    • ttn (ttn_dtype) - Copy construct TTN object

    • slice (ms_ttn_slice_dtype) - Construct TTN object from slice of multiset ttn

    • tree (ntree) - Construct TTN from an Ntree object

    • string (str) - Construct TTN from an string defining an Ntree object

  • dtype ({np.float64, np.complex128}, optional) – The dtype to use for the site operator. (Default: np.complex128)

  • **kwargs – Additional keyword arguments that are based to the ttn object constructor

Returns:

The Tree Tensor Network State object

Return type:

ttn_real or ttn_complex
